awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Anatomy of a Greenhouse World: The Early Eocene of the Green River Basin, Wyoming
awd_abstract_narration:
The geologic record of past environmental change offers an illuminating glimpse into the behavior of Earth's natural systems.  The deposits formed in ancient lakes are particularly useful in this regard for several reasons:  they are highly sensitive to climate change; they often contain relatively complete geologic archives with relatively few gaps; and they can potentially be used to document changes that occurred over time scales meaningful to humans.  The Green River Formation in the western U.S. offers an especially valuable record of the most geologically recent period of prolonged greenhouse conditions, which occurred approximately 50-53 million years ago during the Eocene Epoch.  It is famous for its rich assemblages of fossil vertebrates, insects, and plants, and for containing the world's largest commercial deposits of soda ash and oil shale.  This research project will focus on evidence for repeated rapid warming events during this time, by examining how river courses changed, the types of sediment that accumulated within the lake, and variations in ancient soil development and chemistry.  Equally important, this study will build a time scale of unprecedented accuracy and precision for these important deposits, based on new radiometric dates of volcanic ash in the lake, the chronology of changes in the Earth's magnetic field, and sedimentation patterns that were driven by periodic oscillations in the Earth's rotation and orbit.  Broader impacts of this proposal will include development of local 2-hour field trips for middle and high school students, enhanced through the use of innovative data visualization technology on portable devices.   

The Early Eocene Climatic Optimum (EECO) was a time of persistent global warmth, of which the cause remains incompletely determined.  Lake deposits of the Green River Formation preserve a rich and previously untapped record that complements that contained in marine sediments, and present an opportunity to advance the precision and accuracy of the Early Eocene timescale.  This project is an integrated, multidisciplinary investigation focused on one of the world's richest and best studied systems of ancient lake strata. The research will investigate three principal questions: 1. How did the timing of terrestrial warming compare to that inferred from the marine record, and to predicted patterns of the Earth's orbital variations?  Recent advances in radioisotopic dating can be used to directly test the relationship of warming events to Earth's orbital changes, and calibrate dynamic gravitational models of the solar system back to ca. 50 million years. 2. How did temperatures, seasonality, hydrologic cycling, and weathering on land evolve during the EECO? One hypothesis is that warming was amplified on continents relative to the oceans and was accompanied by more equable temperatures year-round, whereas precipitation seasonality and intensity increased. 3. How did the complex tectonic and magmatic evolution of western North America impact the preservation of EECO climate signals?  The research will test the hypothesis that repeated, stepwise drainage reorganizations within the tectonically-active uplands modified the hydrologic balance and sedimentary deposits of the Eocene lake environment and its response to orbital changes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ancient lake and river deposits in southwestern Wyoming provide a complex, detailed record of multiple abrupt warming episodes (“hyperthermals”) that occurred approximately 50 million years ago, which are a central theme of this research project. We find that the sensitivity of the ancient lake to the sequence of warming events, and the resulting geological record preserved in their sedimentary deposits, varied with the changing influence of rivers that discharged into the lake basin. High rates of river discharge resulted in relatively freshwater lakes that were less sensitive to transient climate change. In contrast, the diversion of a major river away from the lake basin resulted in enhanced sensitivity to climate changes, causing pronounced fluctuations in the deposition of river versus salty lake deposits. The latter includes the world’s largest commercial accumulation of sodium bicarbonate salts. 

  

Our analyses of radioactive potassium and uranium (radioisotopes), in volcanically-formed minerals that are now preserved within the lake deposits, permitted establishment of a new high-resolution age framework (geologic clock) for the warming episodes, with age uncertainties as small as ~10,000 years. For comparison, this uncertainty is approximately equivalent to 17 seconds out of a 24-hour day. The new geologic age model demonstrates that the major wet-dry climate fluctuations recorded in the lake sediments recurred approximately every 100,000 years.   

 

The regular repetition of lake cycles was also associated with regular fluctuations in chemistry of the lake sediment, measured using X-ray fluorescence scanning of 257 meters of drill core at a vertical resolution of 5 mm. The chemical data from these scans indicate that Eocene climate was influenced by periodic changes in the Earth’s orbital configuration, including the eccentricity of its orbit (round vs. elliptical), the obliquity (tilt) of its axis, and the precession (“wobble”) of its axis. The pronounced 100,000 cycles correspond to eccentricity, as expected, but we also found that the relative power associated with the three astronomical components changed through the sedimentary succession. We infer that the modulation of the celestial “signal” itself did not fundamentally change through this transition, but that its “reception” was modified by a tectonic change in basin configuration. 

 

The high-resolution age framework also allows for a direct comparison of eccentricity cycles to a mathematical “astronomical” model for Earth’s orbital configurations that extends back 50 million years. Despite the increasing influence of chaotic astronomical interactions with time, we found a close relationship between model-predicted eccentricity maxima and lacustrine flooding surfaces. These flooding surfaces also appear to correspond with the previously proposed hypothermal events identified using marine records, allowing us to link the response of marine and terrestrial environments to the cyclic, astronomically-paced warming episodes. 

 

Broader Impacts 

To enhance the dissemination of methodological approaches developed and applied in this project, and to help cultivate future leaders in geoscience, we held a seven-day IsoAstro Geochronology Workshop at Western Wyoming Community College (June 5-11, 2019). This location afforded the opportunity for a day-long field trip to examine the lake and river deposits of the ~50 million year old Green River Formation, the focus of our project. The IsoAstro Geochronology Workshop included 47 participants (undergraduates, graduates, researchers, faculty) representing a cross-section of U.S. states plus six other countries. This workshop provided a novel opportunity to learn how radioisotopic and astronomical clocks are best integrated to address earth science problems. 

 

Expanding the reach of this project to the broader public, this awarded supported 1) the creation of a short film, “Chasing Sands”, which communicates the rationale and impact of the research to the general public, 2) an online, virtually explorable 3D model of a Green River Formation geological study site, and 3) additional educational video content for introductory geology that features the geological study sites, which is being used to teach geoscience at UW-Madison, and is freely available online. 

 

A graduate student whose MS thesis research at UW-Madison, and a publication in a peer-reviewed journal, were supported by this grant is currently a teacher of physics, earth science, and biology at Renaissance High School in Meridian Idaho (suburb of Boise). This highly ranked school emphasizes excellence in STEM education and preparing students to succeed in college.  Thus, the hands-on geoscience research experience that the grant provided should, in a transitive manner, have a positive impact on future generations of scientists. One hopes that a few geoscientists will emerge from this group. 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Alan R Carroll
por.por_txt_cntn:
Ancient lake and river deposits in southwestern Wyoming provide a complex, detailed record of multiple abrupt warming episodes (hyperthermals) that occurred approximately 50 million years ago, which are a central theme of this research project. We find that the sensitivity of the ancient lake to the sequence of warming events, and the resulting geological record preserved in their sedimentary deposits, varied with the changing influence of rivers that discharged into the lake basin. High rates of river discharge resulted in relatively freshwater lakes that were less sensitive to transient climate change. In contrast, the diversion of a major river away from the lake basin resulted in enhanced sensitivity to climate changes, causing pronounced fluctuations in the deposition of river versus salty lake deposits. The latter includes the worlds largest commercial accumulation of sodium bicarbonate salts.









Our analyses of radioactive potassium and uranium (radioisotopes), in volcanically-formed minerals that are now preserved within the lake deposits, permitted establishment of a new high-resolution age framework (geologic clock) for the warming episodes, with age uncertainties as small as ~10,000 years. For comparison, this uncertainty is approximately equivalent to 17 seconds out of a 24-hour day. The regular repetition of lake cycles was also associated with regular fluctuations in chemistry of the lake sediment, measured using X-ray fluorescence scanning of 257 meters of drill core at a vertical resolution of 5 mm. The chemical data from these scans indicate that Eocene climate was influenced by periodic changes in the Earths orbital configuration, including the eccentricity of its orbit (round vs. elliptical), the obliquity (tilt) of its axis, and the precession (wobble) of its axis. The pronounced 100,000 cycles correspond to eccentricity, as expected, but we also found that the relative power associated with the three astronomical components changed through the sedimentary succession. We infer that the modulation of the celestial signal itself did not fundamentally change through this transition, but that its reception was modified by a tectonic change in basin configuration.









The high-resolution age framework also allows for a direct comparison of eccentricity cycles to a mathematical astronomical model for Earths orbital configurations that extends back 50 million years. Despite the increasing influence of chaotic astronomical interactions with time, we found a close relationship between model-predicted eccentricity maxima and lacustrine flooding surfaces. These flooding surfaces also appear to correspond with the previously proposed hypothermal events identified using marine records, allowing us to link the response of marine and terrestrial environments to the cyclic, astronomically-paced warming episodes.









Broader Impacts




To enhance the dissemination of methodological approaches developed and applied in this project, and to help cultivate future leaders in geoscience, we held a seven-day IsoAstro Geochronology Workshop at Western Wyoming Community College (June 5-11, 2019). This location afforded the opportunity for a day-long field trip to examine the lake and river deposits of the ~50 million year old Green River Formation, the focus of our project. This workshop provided a novel opportunity to learn how radioisotopic and astronomical clocks are best integrated to address earth science problems.









Expanding the reach of this project to the broader public, this awarded supported 1) the creation of a short film, Chasing Sands, which communicates the rationale and impact of the research to the general public, 2) an online, virtually explorable 3D model of a Green River Formation geological study site, and 3) additional educational video content for introductory geology that features the geological study sites, which is being used to teach geoscience at UW-Madison, and is freely available online.









A graduate student whose MS thesis research at UW-Madison, and a publication in a peer-reviewed journal, were supported by this grant is currently a teacher of physics, earth science, and biology at Renaissance High School in Meridian Idaho (suburb of Boise). This highly ranked school emphasizes excellence in STEM education and preparing students to succeed in college. Thus, the hands-on geoscience research experience that the grant provided should, in a transitive manner, have a positive impact on future generations of scientists. One hopes that a few geoscientists will emerge from this group.
